UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS • URBANA
Office of University Broadcasting
October 8, 1952
Mr. Gray don Ausraus
Box 2002
University of Alabama
University, Alabama
Dear Graydon:
Unfortunately, I can give you very little help in making your
decision on Earl Wynn. I have met Earl once or twice and then
only briefly, llty impression of him is very favorable. Further,
I know a good many people who are aquainted with him and with
his work and their reports always have been good.
This is an important decision and I am sorry that I can’t help
you in making it. I assume that you have solicited a reaction
from John Ivy, and if you have not done so, I would urge that you
query Professor Gordon Blackwell at Chapel Hill about Wynn,
his capacity to deal with people,and his capacity for intellectual
growth.
The FAE’s committee on training in the mass media held its first
meeting last week and proposes immediately to make a few grants
for interneships while it continues to work on plans for a long
range program of training. I have drawn the assignment of coming
up with some nominations of internees in educational radio and
television. If you have some suggestions to make of people who
could profit from an interneship experience, especially those
in situations which are critical just now, I hope you will send
them on to me at once.
Best **»»*»■•*'* «
Robert B. Hudson
Director
